<![CDATA[Ottawa Citizen - Ottawa News]]>http://ottawacitizen.comOttawa Latest News, Breaking Headlines & SportsSun, 18 Feb 2018 16:36:02 +0000enhourly1http://wordpress.com/https://postmediaottawacitizen2.files.wordpress.com/2017/09/oc-wordmark-250x23.pngOttawa Citizenhttp://ottawacitizen.comOttawa Latest News, Breaking Headlines & SportsWoman in intensive care after Highway 50 crashhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/woman-in-intensive-care-after-highway-50-crashhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/woman-in-intensive-care-after-highway-50-crash#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 16:10:03 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159777A 41-year-old woman injured in a two-car collision on Highway 50 Saturday is in intensive care in life-threatening condition, according to Quebec police.

The woman and her daughter were travelling westbound on the highway in Gatineau around 4 p.m. when their vehicle collided with a vehicle they were attempting to pass. 

The woman then lost control of her vehicle, which rolled over multiple times. The woman and her 19-year-old daughter were ejected from the vehicle. The daughter is in stable condition.

Two occupants in the other vehicle sustained minor injuries

Police had closed the highway but reopened it Saturday evening. 

With files from Canadian Press 

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/woman-in-intensive-care-after-highway-50-crash/feed0Police Car Emergency Lights STKsyogaretnamWeather: Latest warmer weather forecast leads to pothole caution from cityhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/weather-lastest-warmer-weather-forecast-leads-to-pothole-caution-from-cityhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/weather-lastest-warmer-weather-forecast-leads-to-pothole-caution-from-city#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 13:13:26 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159429It’s the last weekend of Winterlude and, while celebrants couldn’t ask for better weather, but the warmish temperatures could have some unplesant side effects.

The Rideau Skateway reopened Saturday after a warm weather rest, but officials are keeping an eagle eye on conditions.

The upcoming thaw also prompted an alert from the city about a new crop of potholes.

Another thaw = more potholes on the road, but you can help! Report location online https://t.co/Qmr6AVPSa8 so we can send crews to fill them.

— City of Ottawa (@ottawacity) February 17, 2018

The skies are expected to clear up Sunday morning, with a high of about 2 C. Clouds should roll back in Sunday night with a low of -4 C.

Springlike conditions are expected through the week with highs above zero most of the week.

Monday should see a 40 per cent chance of rain  and a high of 6 C. More rain is expected Monday night and a low of 5 C.

Tuesday is expected to see a summery high of 11 C with rain showers, and low of 1 C, with more precipitation.

By midweek, the high is expected to be 2 C Wednesday, with more rain or snow.Wednesday’s low is expected to drop to -7 C.

Thursday marks a slight return to winterish conditions with a mix of sun and cloud and a high of -1 C. The low should be around -11 C.

Friday looks like more flurries with a high of -2 C.

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/weather-lastest-warmer-weather-forecast-leads-to-pothole-caution-from-city/feed0021718-stcPotholenprovenchShot fired during holdup at Vanier cannabis dispensaryhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/shot-fired-during-holdup-at-vanier-cannabis-dispensaryhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/shot-fired-during-holdup-at-vanier-cannabis-dispensary#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 05:08:58 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159525Ottawa police are investigating an armed robbery at a Vanier pot shop Saturday afternoon that saw a shot fired by one of three assailants who fled with cash and drugs.

Police were called to 613 Medicinals at 274 Montreal Rd. on Saturday afternoon.

One person inside the dispensary was assaulted during the robbery but was not injured as a result of gunfire. Police said the person’s injuries were considered minor.

Police had cordoned off the shop for their investigation before the illegal marijuana dispensary closed for the day around 4 p.m.

No arrests had been made by early Saturday evening.

The Ottawa police robbery squad continues to investigate.

It was the city’s 17th shooting of 2018. 

A raid by the force’s drug unit in December 2016 revealed that the dispensary, at that time, was selling drugs and a variety of edibles. 

All marijuana dispensaries operating in the city are illegal storefronts. They are also not expected to be part of the pending marijuana legalization framework. Police have urged them to shut down.

syogaretnam@postmedia.com

twitter.com/shaaminiwhy

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/shot-fired-during-holdup-at-vanier-cannabis-dispensary/feed0021718-potshopsyogaretnam$300,000 blaze displaces 38 residents of Gatineau apartment complexhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/300000-blaze-displaces-38-residents-of-gatineau-apartment-complexhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/300000-blaze-displaces-38-residents-of-gatineau-apartment-complex#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 04:54:49 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159655A fire Saturday evening caused approximately $300,000 in damage and forced 38 resident out of an apartment complex in Gatineau.

The Gatineau fire department said the blaze at 160 rue de Lausanne, a short distance from the Tecumseh Golf Club, was reported just before 7 p.m. It was reportedly under control by just before 9 p.m.

The blaze was under investigation by fire department investigators, but had not been referred to Gatineau police, a media release said.

One apartment was destroyed and another immediately above it was badly damaged. All 38 residents of the three-storey, 18-apartment complex were safely evacuated and were referred to the Canadian Red Cross, the media release added.

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/300000-blaze-displaces-38-residents-of-gatineau-apartment-complex/feed0051414-STK_FIRETRUCK-W.jpg-114947-city_002.JPG-POS2014051409035133gordholderOttawa police seeking assistance in identifying woman wanted in connection with thefts, fraudhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/ottawa-police-seeking-assistance-in-identifying-woman-wanted-in-connection-with-thefts-fraudhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/ottawa-police-seeking-assistance-in-identifying-woman-wanted-in-connection-with-thefts-fraud#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 04:06:48 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159645

Ottawa police are seeking public assistance in identifying this woman Ottawa Police Service photo.

Ottawa police have issued a request for public assistance in identifying a woman sought in connection with theft and fraud offences committed in a “centrally located mall” in January.

A media released distributed Saturday said the woman allegedly took shopping bags, purses or packsacks while their owners were distracted or had left belongings unattended for a few minutes. The credit cards were then used to make fraudulent purchases, police added.

The woman was described as being in her mid-thirties to mid-forties and with a medium build and dark brown, shoulder-length hair.

Anyone with information about the woman was asked to contact the Ottawa Police Services central criminal investigation unit at 613-236-1222 ext 5166.

This is another police image of the woman they’re seeking in connection with thefts and fraud at a centrally located shopping mall. Ottawa Police Service photo.

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/ottawa-police-seeking-assistance-in-identifying-woman-wanted-in-connection-with-thefts-fraud/feed0092514-11842305.JPG-POS1409241244463218-X000-STK_POLICE_HQ-W.jpggordholderPolice looking for Ottawa-area teen after laptop thefts at universitieshttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/police-looking-for-ottawa-area-teen-after-laptop-thefts-at-universitieshttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/police-looking-for-ottawa-area-teen-after-laptop-thefts-at-universities#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 03:04:09 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159620An arrest warrant has been requested for a 19-year-old from the national capital area after several high-end laptops were stolen at local universities.

Marcus Matamba has been charged with six counts of theft under $5,000 and six counts of breach of probation, Ottawa police said in a news release Saturday night.

The thefts took place between Jan. 11 and Feb. 9, and usually occurred in study areas while targeted students momentarily left their computers unattended, police said.

Matamba was described as standing about 5-9 (175 cm) and weighing 123 pounds (56 kg). Anyone with information on his current whereabouts was asked to call police at 613-236-1222, ext. 5166 or Crime Stoppers.

The Central Criminal Investigation Unit has requested an arrest warrant for 19-year-old Marcus Matamba.

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/police-looking-for-ottawa-area-teen-after-laptop-thefts-at-universities/feed0021718-Census_Commuting_20171129dmenary2014Funeral held for slain great grandmother allegedly beaten to death by sonhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/funeral-held-for-slain-great-grandmother-allegedly-beaten-to-death-by-sonhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/funeral-held-for-slain-great-grandmother-allegedly-beaten-to-death-by-son#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 00:39:10 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159534Slain great grandmother Maria Desousa was remembered Saturday at a Portuguese-language funeral service at Our Lady of Fatima Parish in Kingston where friends and family gathered to mourn her. 

Desousa, 81, was described in her obituary as the “loved mother” of three children, including her Ottawa son — the youngest of the family — who now sits behind bars charged, alongside his girlfriend, after what police believe was a premeditated plot to murder his elderly mother. 

Paulo Desousa, 40, and Danielle LeBlanc, 36, allegedly drove Maria’s body to the Montfort Hospital on Feb. 10. Police allege the couple had beaten Maria, who lived with them, to death days earlier.

Police believe Maria Desousa, who had moved from Kingston, was killed in the Orléans townhome all three shared on Parkrose Private.

A funeral for homicide victim Maria Desousa was held at Kingston’s Our Lady of Fatima Church on Saturday, Feb. 17, 2018.

Police documents filed in court say Desousa was killed on Feb. 8 — two days before she was finally brought to the hospital. Police initially believed that the couple’s account of Maria’s final moments was suspicious. Investigators later classified it a homicide.

Police arrived at the Orléans street they lived on late in the afternoon of the day the couple arrived at hospital with Maria’s body.

The couple appeared in court Tuesday, when they were each formally charged with first-degree murder. 

LeBlanc appeared with bandages over her nose and brow. 

There have been six homicides in Ottawa in 2018.

syogaretnam@postmedia.com

twitter.com/shaaminiwhy

Police are seen outside a townhome at 277 Parkrose Private in Orléans after Maria Desousa’s body had been brought to the Montfort Hospital.

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/funeral-held-for-slain-great-grandmother-allegedly-beaten-to-death-by-son/feed0021718-desousa.JPGsyogaretnamScanlan: Woodhouse wheels about town doing community service in his new chairhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/scanlan-woodhouse-wheels-about-town-doing-community-service-in-his-new-chairhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/scanlan-woodhouse-wheels-about-town-doing-community-service-in-his-new-chair#respondSun, 18 Feb 2018 00:26:03 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1158310It’s amazing what a friend’s Facebook post can do.

Especially when the post leads to a small newspaper story about a determined, independent man in a wheelchair — and a persistent gym manager campaigning on his client’s behalf.

Following a string of advocacy measures, John Woodhouse has a new power wheelchair today, a replacement ride from the Ontario Disability Support Program, several months ahead of the usual replacement schedule of five years.

Woodhouse, 63, who volunteers all over the city to make life better for people with mobility issues, logs a lot of miles in his chair. Woodhouse takes two OC Transpo buses to get from Vanier to his regular 10 a.m. workout at the Soloway Jewish Community Centre (JCC) in the west end.

The lower part of Woodhouse’s rear-wheel-drive, multi-thousand-dollar Xplore 2 power chair was coated in mud and salt, which gym manager Ryan Armitage quickly cleaned off before Woodhouse entered the gym. Woodhouse drove his chair back and forth on a patch of cloth to clean the wheels.

“I’ve seen a big change in John (since getting the chair),” Armitage says. “He’s just, happier. It’s been amazing.”

A chair provided by the ministry of health before Christmas was appreciated but not functional for someone like Woodhouse, who ventures outside in all manner of weather.

“The first chair was a mid-wheel drive and those are good for apartments, because you can literally turn on a dime,” Woodhouse says. “They are very manoeuvrable. But in winter conditions they don’t stand up to the task.”

Crystal Bastien, a Vanier neighbour of Woodhouse, first posted a Facebook blog and video in September about Woodhouse’s deteriorating wheelchair, which was rusting and smelly. That led to a story in this newspaper about Woodhouse’s dilemma, which Armitage included in a letter to Ontario’s minister of health and long-term care, Eric Hoskins. Woodhouse’s chair was finally approved.

“I am so happy for him,” Bastien said of John’s new ride in a text message. “He deserves it and more.”

Working out helped turn John Woodhouse’s life around.

Woodhouse quickly donated his other new chair to Stride Wheelchairs Plus, which provides mobility equipment for those in need.

The wheels of John’s chair are a neat symbol for the circle of giving in this story. While his supporters help out Woodhouse, in turn he gives back to the community in spades. Since his cause was made public, he has received myriad offers of help, including cash, and declined it all, directing it to Stride instead.

Woodhouse volunteers for the Healthy Transportation Coalition and for eight years has been doing “walk audits” for the Council on Aging of Ottawa, ensuring that elderly and disabled can safely get from Point A to B. He’s the chairperson for Walk Ottawa. The chair, in the chair.

“You actually have to see it to believe it,” Woodhouse says of his transport audits.

“People say, ‘Oh, you’re exaggerating.’ But sometimes it feels like you’re doing moguls when you’re riding down the sidewalk.”

Woodhouse, who used to work in a publishing warehouse, was hit hard with dystonia, a neurological disease that causes involuntary muscle contractions and tremors that impact movement and speech. He self-medicated with alcohol, which caused his health to deteriorate. Nine years ago, he was admitted to hospital with severe infections in both legs, which had to be amputated just below the hips.

Woodhouse pulled himself together, quit drinking and started working out at the JCC with Armitage. He left his long-term care facility to live on his own, able to cook and care for himself thanks to his improved strength and self-esteem.

His own family, which includes two older brothers and a younger sister, has come back into his life after seeing the personal strides he has taken.

“I had to open up to them and say, ‘I don’t just sit around anymore and watch TV and drink beer,’ ” Woodhouse says.

John Woodhouse gets a hand from JCC gym manager Ryan Armitage during a workout.

His clean summer look is gone, replaced by a greying winter beard and thick, long hair. He says the growth keeps him warm, as his muscle limitations prevent him from pulling on a hat.

As Armitage helps him take off his coat for the workout, Woodhouse unveils a bright red Ottawa Senators T-shirt, which naturally sparks a reaction, given the NHL team’s struggles.

A woman walking by says, “Are you sure you want a picture of yourself in that shirt?”

Laughter ensues. But Woodhouse, one of the Senators’ true believers, holds firm.

“It’s so easy to be negative,” Woodhouse says. “I’m like (owner) Eugene Melnyk, I do have a dream.”

A health company anonymously offered nutritional supplements to fuel his workouts and recovery, but Woodhouse would only accept if the company documented his experience to help others who are physically or mentally challenged.

His message to all: Be active. Volunteer.

“I just hope more people get out and do something. Anything,” Woodhouse says. “Don’t just sit at home and think that’s all there is.”

Reminded what an inspiration his lifestyle is to others, Woodhouse says, whimsically:

“It’s because I have nothing else to do.”

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/scanlan-woodhouse-wheels-about-town-doing-community-service-in-his-new-chair/feed0021718-Woodhouse_468.JPGwaynescanlanThree displaced in Gatineau mobile home firehttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/three-displaced-in-gatineau-mobile-home-firehttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/three-displaced-in-gatineau-mobile-home-fire#respondSat, 17 Feb 2018 22:43:20 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159416Three people were displaced following a stubborn fire in a mobile home in Gatineau’s west end late Friday night.

Firefighters were called to the residence at 38 Fifth Ave. W., near Highway 50 and La Vérendrye Boulevard, shortly before midnight.

The Gatineau fire department deployed a dozen trucks and 24 firefighters to the scene.

They found one of the residents attempting to put out the fire. She was treated for minor injuries at the scene.

The Red Cross took the three residents to shelter.

The cause of the fire in not yet determined. Damage was estimated at $100,000.

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/three-displaced-in-gatineau-mobile-home-fire/feed0120317-WC1_4193nprovenchFormer MP Paul Dewar being treated for brain cancerhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/former-mp-paul-dewar-being-treated-for-brain-cancerhttp://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/former-mp-paul-dewar-being-treated-for-brain-cancer#respondSat, 17 Feb 2018 21:50:05 +0000http://ottawacitizen.com/?p=1159399Former Ottawa Centre MP Paul Dewar is being treated for brain cancer, he revealed Saturday morning.

The first symptom he felt was numbness in his arm, he wrote in a public Facebook post, which he put down to tiredness from a 36-kilometre skate on the Rideau Canal on Jan. 26. But instead of getting better, the numbness persisted.

“On Monday February 5, I went to the Ottawa Civic Hospital to have my arm examined. X-rays, and then a CT scan, revealed a cyst on the right side of (my) brain,” Dewar wrote. “A follow up MRI revealed it was a tumour.”

On Wednesday, surgeons removed it.

“While this cancer is devastating news, I am going to pursue the next phase of my treatment with determination, passion and an appreciation for life,” Dewar said.

His post didn’t specify what form of cancer he has. Brain tumours come in many forms — different sorts of cancerous cells, in different parts of the brain, growing at different rates — with a wide range of prognoses. That the tumour could be removed surgically is a good sign but not as important as the type of cancer. Five-year survival rates range from five per cent to more than 85 per cent.

“Everyone of us knows someone who has had cancer and each journey is personal. People ask what they can do. If you can, please consider getting involved in something that will help your neighbourhood. Look for the beauty that exists all around us and share it with each other,” Dewar wrote.

Dewar did write that he looks forward to getting “back to my usual level of physical and community activity” over a few months.

Aged 55, Dewar is a distance runner, cyclist and skater. Since his surgery, he’s been tweeting busily about the Olympics.

I believe in @TeamHoman! Sending out the positive vibes from home #PyeongChang2018 #Ottawa #GoTeamHoman https://t.co/y0EvigsO8j

— Paul Dewar (@PaulDewar) February 16, 2018

Dewar was the New Democratic Party MP for Ottawa Centre for nine years, until he lost his seat to Liberal Catherine McKenna in the 2015 election. A former teacher and union leader, he’s also the son of Ottawa’s late former mayor Marion Dewar.

Since he left federal politics, he’s joined the board of Human Rights Watch and consulted abroad on democratic reforms. He’s also been touted as a possible left-wing challenger to Jim Watson for the mayor’s office this year, and in January he said he was actively thinking about running.

Watson, among many others, wished Dewar a speedy recovery.

Wishing @PaulDewar a full and speedy recovery after his surgery. And our thoughts are also with your family and many friends. Get well Paul!

— Jim Watson (@JimWatsonOttawa) February 17, 2018

Dewar’s diagnosis was also the talk of the federal NDP’s convention in Ottawa, where MPs Charlie Angus and Hélène Laverdière announced the news and delegates stood to show their support with applause.

Praying for my friend Paul Dewar and his family. He is such a force of integrity and decency. Praying for good health and recovery.

— Charlie Angus NDP (@CharlieAngusNDP) February 17, 2018

With supportive family and friends, Dewar wrote, “I am perched by the side of a strong flowing river of love that gives me the courage and inspiration to take on this challenge.”

dreevely@postmedia.com
twitter.com/davidreevely

]]>http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/former-mp-paul-dewar-being-treated-for-brain-cancer/feed0102015-JLEV8871.jpg-1021_elxn_dewar-W.jpgdavidreevely
